The Metric Function

Axioms of the Metric Space

  • A metric space is a set XXX equipped with a distance function d:X×X→Rd: X\times X \to \mathbb{R}d:X×X→R that satisfies the following axioms:
    • Positive-definiteness: d(x,y)≥0d(x,y)\ge 0d(x,y)≥0, with equality only when x=yx=yx=y.
    • Symmetry: d(x,y)=d(y,x)d(x,y)=d(y,x)d(x,y)=d(y,x).
    • Triangular inequality: d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z)d(x,y)+d(y,z)\ge d(x,z)d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z).
  • A distance function is also called a metric.
  • If the set XXX is also a vector space, then a function ∥∗∥:X→R\|*\|:X \to \mathbb{R}∥∗∥:X→R is called a norm if it satisfies:
    • Positive-definiteness: ∥x∥≥0\|x\|\ge 0∥x∥≥0, with equality only when x=0x=0x=0.
    • Linear scaling: ∥λx∥=∣λ∣∥x∥\|\lambda x\|=|\lambda|\|x\|∥λx∥=∣λ∣∥x∥
    • Triangle inequality: ∥x+y∥≤∥x∥+∥y∥\|x+y\| \le\|x\|+\|y\|∥x+y∥≤∥x∥+∥y∥
  • Given a norm on XXX, it induces the metric d(x,y)=∥x−y∥d(x,y)=\|x-y\|d(x,y)=∥x−y∥.

Common Metrics and Norms

  • In Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, the l1,l2,l∞l_{1},l_{2},l_{\infty}l1​,l2​,l∞​ norms of x=(xi)i=1n\mathbf{x}=(x_{i})_{i=1}^{n}x=(xi​)i=1n​ are given byl1(x)=∑i∣xi∣l2(x)=∑ixi2l∞(x)=sup⁡i∣xi∣\begin{align*} &l_{1}(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{i}|x_{i}|\\ &l_{2}(\mathbf{x})=\sqrt{ \sum_{i} x_{i}^2 }\\ &l_{\infty}(\mathbf{\mathbf{x}})=\sup_{i}|x_{i}| \end{align*}​l1​(x)=i∑​∣xi​∣l2​(x)=i∑​xi2​​l∞​(x)=isup​∣xi​∣​and the metrics they induce are called d1,d2,d∞d_{1},d_{2},d_{\infty}d1​,d2​,d∞​. Note that d2d_{2}d2​ is just the usual Euclidean distance.
  • In any set, the discrete metric d(x,y)=1x≠yd(x,y)=\mathbb{1}_{x\ne y}d(x,y)=1x=y​ is a metric. It’s often a good counterexample to seemingly legit statements.
  • In the vector space B(X)B(X)B(X), the set of functions bounded on XXX, the supremum norm induces the supremum metric: $$\begin{align*}
    |f|_{\infty}&= \sup{ f(x): x \in X }\\

d_{\infty}(f,g)&= |f-g|_{\infty}
\end{align*}$$

  • On the set C(A)C(A)C(A), the set of functions continuous on an interval AAA, the map d1(f,g)=∫A∣f−g∣ dxd_{1}(f,g)=\int _{A} |f-g| \, dxd1​(f,g)=∫A​∣f−g∣dx is a metric.

Product Spaces

  • Given metric spaces X,YX,YX,Y, the set X×YX\times YX×Y forms a metric space with the product metric: dX×Y=dX2+dY2d_{X\times Y}=\sqrt{d_X^2+d_Y^2}dX×Y​=dX2​+dY2​​
  • For example, (R2,d2)=R×R(\mathbb{R}^{2},d_{2})=\mathbb{R}\times \mathbb{R}(R2,d2​)=R×R.
  • A sequence ((xn,yn))⊆X×Y((x_n,y_n))\subseteq X\times Y((xn​,yn​))⊆X×Y converges   ⟺  \iff⟺ the two component sequences (xn),(yn)(x_n),(y_n)(xn​),(yn​) converge in X,YX,YX,Y.

(⇒\Rightarrow⇒) by sandwiching dX(xn,x),dY(yn,y)d_X(x_n,x),d_Y(y_n,y)dX​(xn​,x),dY​(yn​,y) between dX×Yd_{X\times Y}dX×Y​ and 000.
(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) by AOL.

Open and Closed Sets

Disks/Balls

  • The (open/closed) ball in the metric space XXX around a point x0x_{0}x0​ of radius rrr is open: B(x0,r)={x∈X:d(x,x0)<r}closed: Bˉ(x0,r)={x∈X:d(x,x0)≤r}\begin{align*} \text{open}: \,&B(x_{0}, r)= \{ x\in X:d(x,x_{0})<r \}\\ \text{closed}: \,&\bar{B}(x_{0},r) = \{ x \in X: d(x,x_{0})\le r \} \end{align*}open:closed:​B(x0​,r)={x∈X:d(x,x0​)<r}Bˉ(x0​,r)={x∈X:d(x,x0​)≤r}​and if necessary, use superscript to indicate the metric used: BdX(x0,r)B^{d_{X}}(x_{0},r)BdX​(x0​,r).
  • Note that given different metrics, this set is not necessarily “round”, and it might be things like:
    • A diamond in (R2,d1)(\mathbb{R}^2,d_{1})(R2,d1​) and a square in (R2,d∞)(\mathbb{R}^{2},d_{\infty})(R2,d∞​)
    • A single point (r<1r<1r<1) or the entire set (r≥1r \ge 1r≥1) under the discrete metric
    • A set of functions in (B(X),d∞)(B(X),d_{\infty})(B(X),d∞​)

Open and Closedness

  • A subset A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X in the metric space is an open set when: ∀a∈A, ∃r>0:B(a,r)⊆A\forall a \in A,\, \exists r>0: B(a,r) \subseteq A∀a∈A,∃r>0:B(a,r)⊆A
    • That is, there is some elbow-room around each point (quoted from Sutherland).
    • By definition, the empty set and the metric space itself are open (hence it is sometimes important to specify the metric space: [a,b][a,b][a,b] is open in itself, but not in R\mathbb{R}R).
  • A subset is a closed set when its complement is open.
    • Closed sets are not necessarily “not open”: by definition, the empty set and the entire space are both closed and open.
    • Sets can also be neither closed or open, for example [0,1)⊂R[0,1) \subset \mathbb{R}[0,1)⊂R.

Basic Results

  • An open ball B(x,r)⊆XB(x, r) \subseteq XB(x,r)⊆X is an open set.

Proof: take any point y∈B(x,y)y \in B(x,y)y∈B(x,y), and write l=d(x,y)<rl=d(x,y)<rl=d(x,y)<r.
Then consider the open ball B∗=B(y,(r−l)2)B^*=B\left(y, \frac{(r-l)}{2} \right)B∗=B(y,2(r−l)​). Any point z∈B∗z \in B^*z∈B∗ must be within a distance of rrr from xxx due to the triangle inequality.
Hence ∃δ=r−l2:B(y,δ)⊆B(x,r)\exists \delta=\frac{r-l}{2}: B(y,\delta) \subseteq B(x,r)∃δ=2r−l​:B(y,δ)⊆B(x,r), and B(x,r)B(x,r)B(x,r) is an open set.

  • A finite intersection of open sets is also open.
    • Could fail for an infinite intersection: {0}=∩n∈N(−1n,1n)\{ 0 \}=\cap_{n\in \mathbb{N}}\left( -\frac{1}{n}, \frac{1}{n} \right){0}=∩n∈N​(−n1​,n1​) is closed in R\mathbb{R}R.

Proof: assume AiA_{i}Ai​ all open for i∈{1,…,n}i \in \{ 1, \dots, n \}i∈{1,…,n}, and take any x∈∩iAix \in\cap_{i} A_{i}x∈∩i​Ai​.
The definition of open sets gives ri:B(x,ri)⊆Air_{i}:B(x,r_{i}) \subseteq A_{i}ri​:B(x,ri​)⊆Ai​, and take their minimum r=min⁡{ri}r=\min\{ r_{i} \}r=min{ri​} (positive since the intersection is finite). Then verify that B(x,r)⊆∩iAiB(x,r) \subseteq \cap_{i} A_{i}B(x,r)⊆∩i​Ai​.

  • An arbitrary (finite or infinite) union of open sets is also open.
    • Hence in R\mathbb{R}R, (a,∞)=∪n∈N(a+1n,a+n)(a,\infty)=\cup_{n\in \mathbb{N}}\left( a+\frac{1}{n},a+n \right)(a,∞)=∪n∈N​(a+n1​,a+n) is open, and (−∞,a]=(a,∞)c(-\infty,a]=(a,\infty)^c(−∞,a]=(a,∞)c is closed.

Proof: assume AiA_{i}Ai​ are all open, and take any x∈∪iAx \in \cup_{i} Ax∈∪i​A, say x∈Anx\in A_{n}x∈An​. Apply the definition of openness on x∈Anx\in A_{n}x∈An​ gives B(x,r)⊆An⊆∪iAiB(x,r) \subseteq A_{n} \subseteq \cup_{i} A_{i}B(x,r)⊆An​⊆∪i​Ai​.

  • A finite union of closed sets is also closed; an arbitrary intersection of closed sets is also closed.

Proof: apply the previous results to their complements.

Closures and Interiors

Limit and Isolated points

  • A limit point of a set YYY in a metric space XXX is a point x∈Xx \in Xx∈X such that: ∀ϵ>0, B(x,ϵ)∩(Y\{x})≠∅\forall \epsilon>0, \ B(x,\epsilon)\cap \big(Y\backslash\{x\}\big)\ne\emptyset∀ϵ>0, B(x,ϵ)∩(Y\{x})=∅
    • That is, xxx is touching YYY, though xxx does not have to be in YYY.
    • E.g. both 000 and 111 are limit points of [0,1)[0,1)[0,1).
    • The set of limit points of YYY is denoted L(Y)L(Y)L(Y).
  • An isolated point of YYY is a point y∈Yy\in Yy∈Y such that: ∃ϵ>0: B(y,ϵ)∩Y={y}\exists\epsilon>0:\ B(y,\epsilon)\cap Y=\{y\}∃ϵ>0: B(y,ϵ)∩Y={y}
    • That is, nothing else is close to yyy in YYY.
  • The union of the limit points and isolated points of YYY is called its points of closure.

Basic Results about Limit Points

  • A point is a limit point iff it can be approached by a sequence: ∃(xn)⊆X,(xn)→x  ⟺  x∈L(X)\exists(x_{n})\subseteq X,(x_{n})\to x \iff x \in L(X)∃(xn​)⊆X,(xn​)→x⟺x∈L(X)

Proof: easy result from the definitions by taking ϵ=1n\epsilon= \frac{1}{ n}ϵ=n1​, for example.

  • A set YYY is closed   ⟺  \iff⟺ it contains all its limit points.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) if for contradiction a limit point xxx is not in YYY closed, then
by openness of YcY^cYc, there is r:B(x,r)⊆Ycr: B(x,r) \subseteq Y^cr:B(x,r)⊆Yc.
Then the definition of a limit point gives y∈Y:y∈B(x,r)⊆Ycy \in Y: y\in B(x,r) \subseteq Y^cy∈Y:y∈B(x,r)⊆Yc, a contradiction.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) we shall show that YcY^cYc is open. For any a∈Yca \in Y^ca∈Yc, if for contradiction ∀ϵ>0,∃y∈Y∩B(a,ϵ)\forall \epsilon>0, \exists y \in Y\cap B(a,\epsilon)∀ϵ>0,∃y∈Y∩B(a,ϵ), then aaa is a limit point of YYY, which by assumption is in YYY, a contradiction. So B(a,ϵ)⊆YcB(a,\epsilon)\subseteq Y^cB(a,ϵ)⊆Yc, YcY^cYc is open, YYY is closed.

  • The set of limit points L(Y)L(Y)L(Y) of subset Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X is closed.

Proof: We will prove that L(Y)cL(Y)^cL(Y)c is open by finding an open ball around any a∈L(Y)ca \in L(Y)^{c}a∈L(Y)c.
Since a∉L(Y)a\not\in L(Y)a∈L(Y), there ∃r>0:B(a,r)∩Y=∅\exists r>0: B(a,r) \cap Y=\emptyset∃r>0:B(a,r)∩Y=∅ or {a}\{ a \}{a}. However, this is not enough as L(Y)⊈YL(Y) \not \subseteq YL(Y)⊆Y in general. We shall show instead that B(a,r/2)B(a, r / 2)B(a,r/2) is the desired open ball.

Fix any b∈B(a,r/2)b \in B(a, r/2)b∈B(a,r/2), and if b=ab=ab=a, then certainly b∈L(Y)cb \in L(Y)^cb∈L(Y)c.
If b≠ab \ne ab=a (see diagram), then B(b,d(a,b)/2)∩Y=∅B(b,d(a,b) / 2) \cap Y=\emptysetB(b,d(a,b)/2)∩Y=∅, so b∈L(Y)cb\in L(Y)^cb∈L(Y)c.
Hence B(a,r/2)⊆L(Y)cB(a,r / 2)\subseteq L(Y)^cB(a,r/2)⊆L(Y)c, and the set is open.

Closures

  • Given a set Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X, its closure is the intersection of all closed sets that contain YYY: Yˉ,Cl(Y),Clo(Y)≡⋂Y⊆UU closedU\bar{Y},\text{Cl}(Y),\text{Clo}(Y)\equiv\bigcap_{\substack{Y\subseteq U\\ U\text{ closed}} }UYˉ,Cl(Y),Clo(Y)≡Y⊆UU closed​⋂​U
    • Closures are different in different metric spaces, so be explicit if necessary: in (0,2)(0,2)(0,2), [1,2)[1,2)[1,2) is its own closure, but in R\mathbb{R}R, its closure is [1,2][1,2][1,2].
  • Equivalent definition: Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ is the smallest closed set that contains YYY.

Proof of equivalence: the closure defined above is an infinite intersection of closed sets, which is also closed.

  • A subset Y⊂XY \subset XY⊂X is dense if Yˉ=X\bar{Y}=XYˉ=X.
    • That is, every point in XXX is touching YYY.
    • For example, Q\mathbb{Q}Q is dense in R\mathbb{R}R.
  • The closure equals the points of closure (the limit and isolated points).
    • Hence the closure of a set is its union with its limit points.

Proof: take Y⊆XY\subseteq XY⊆X, and let Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ be its closure, and L(Y)L(Y)L(Y) be its limit points.
(Yˉ⊆Y∪L(Y)\bar{Y}\subseteq Y \cup L(Y)Yˉ⊆Y∪L(Y)) If for contradiction y∈Yˉy \in \bar{Y}y∈Yˉ is neither a limit or an isolated point, then there is a radius r:B(y,r)∩Y=∅r:B(y,r) \cap Y=\emptysetr:B(y,r)∩Y=∅. Removing this ball from Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ gives a smaller closed set that contains YYY, a contradiction to the (equivalent) definition of closures.

(Yˉ⊇Y∪L(Y)\bar{Y} \supseteq Y \cup L(Y)Yˉ⊇Y∪L(Y)) Obviously isolated points, being within the set, are in the closure. Limit points of YYY are in the closure since they are also limit points of Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ, and the closed set Yˉ\bar{Y}Yˉ contains all its limit points.

Interiors and Boundaries

  • The interior of YYY is the union of all open sets contained in YYY: int(Y), Y˚≡⋃U openU⊂YU\text{int}(Y),\, \mathring{Y} \equiv\bigcup_{\substack{U\text{ open}\\U\subset Y}}Uint(Y),Y˚≡U openU⊂Y​⋃​U
    • For example, int(Q)=∅, int[0,1)=(0,1)\mathrm{int} (\mathbb{Q})=\emptyset,\, \text{int}{[0,1)}=(0,1)int(Q)=∅,int[0,1)=(0,1) in R\mathbb{R}R.
  • Equivalent definition: Y˚\mathring{Y}Y˚ is the largest open subset of YYY.
    • Hence (Y˚)c(\mathring{Y})^c(Y˚)c is the smallest closed set containing YcY^cYc, aka its closure Yc‾\overline{Y^c}Yc.
  • Another equivalent definition: Y˚={y∈Y ∣ ∃ϵ>0:B(y,ϵ)⊆Y}\mathring{Y}=\{ y \in Y \,|\, \exists \epsilon>0: B(y,\epsilon) \subseteq Y \}Y˚={y∈Y∣∃ϵ>0:B(y,ϵ)⊆Y}.
  • The boundary ∂Y\partial Y∂Y of YYY is Yˉ∖Y˚\bar{Y}\setminus \mathring{Y}Yˉ∖Y˚.
    • For example, in R\mathbb{R}R, ∂[0,1]={0,1}\partial [0,1]=\{ 0,1 \}∂[0,1]={0,1}, and ∂Q=R\partial \mathbb{Q}=\mathbb{R}∂Q=R.

Continuity and Convergence

Generalized Definitions

  • A map f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y, where X,YX,YX,Y are metric spaces with metrics dX,dYd_{X},d_{Y}dX​,dY​ respectively, is continuous at x0x_{0}x0​ if: ∀ϵ>0, ∃δ>0:∀x∈X, [dX(x,x0)<δ]⇒[dY(f(x),f(x0))<ϵ]\forall \epsilon>0,\, \exists \delta>0: \forall x\in X,\, [d_{X}(x,x_{0})<\delta] \Rightarrow [d_{Y}(f(x),f(x_{0}))< \epsilon]∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0:∀x∈X,[dX​(x,x0​)<δ]⇒[dY​(f(x),f(x0​))<ϵ]which is the generalization of continuity in (R,l2)(\mathbb{R},l_{2})(R,l2​) learned in Prelims. If necessary, we denote this as (dX,dY)(d_{X},d_{Y})(dX​,dY​)-continuity.
  • Equivalently, the definition can be formulated in terms of disks: ∀ϵ>0, ∃δ>0:f(BdX(x0,δ))⊆BdY(f(x0),ϵ)\forall \epsilon>0,\, \exists \delta>0: f(B^{d_{X}}(x_{0},\delta)) \subseteq B^{d_{Y}}(f(x_{0}), \epsilon)∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0:f(BdX​(x0​,δ))⊆BdY​(f(x0​),ϵ)
  • In a metric space (X,d)(X,d)(X,d), a sequence (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) converges to x∈Xx\in Xx∈X if∀ϵ>0, ∃N∈N:∀n≥N, xn∈Bd(x,ϵ)\forall \epsilon>0,\, \exists N \in \mathbb{N}: \forall n \ge N,\, x_{n}\in B^d(x,\epsilon)∀ϵ>0,∃N∈N:∀n≥N,xn​∈Bd(x,ϵ)
    • Note that convergence requires the limit to be within the metric space: (1n)⊂[0,1]\left( \frac{1}{n} \right) \subset [0,1](n1​)⊂[0,1] converges to 000, but fails to converge in (0,1](0,1](0,1].
  • A sequence (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) is Cauchy in a metric space if ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈N:∀m,n≥N,d(xm,xn)<ϵ\forall \epsilon>0, \exists N \in \mathbb{N}: \forall m,n \ge N, d(x_{m},x_{n}) < \epsilon∀ϵ>0,∃N∈N:∀m,n≥N,d(xm​,xn​)<ϵ

Boundedness

  • A subset A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X in a metric space is bounded if all of it is within a finite distance of a point: ∃x0∈X,r∈R:A⊆B(x0,r)\exists x_{0} \in X, r\in \mathbb{R}: A\subseteq B(x_{0}, r)∃x0​∈X,r∈R:A⊆B(x0​,r)
  • The diameter of a bounded set AAA is diam(A)≡sup⁡x,y∈Ad(x,y)\mathrm{diam}(A)\equiv \sup_{x,y\in A}d(x,y)diam(A)≡supx,y∈A​d(x,y).
  • A function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y is bounded over A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X if f(A)f(A)f(A) is bounded in YYY.
  • Finite unions of bounded sets are bounded.

Proof: say there are bounded subsets A1,…,An⊆XA_{1}, \dots, A_{n}\subseteq XA1​,…,An​⊆X, and the definition of boundedness gives xi,ri:Ai⊆B(xi,ri)x_{i},r_{i}:A_{i} \subseteq B(x_{i},r_{i})xi​,ri​:Ai​⊆B(xi​,ri​).
Take any x0∈Xx_{0}\in Xx0​∈X, and we shall prove that all points of the union are within a certain radius from it.
Write di=d(x0,xi)d_{i}=d(x_{0},x_{i})di​=d(x0​,xi​), then triangular inequality requires ∀a∈Ai,d(a,x0)≤d(a,xi)+d(x0,xi)≤ri+di\forall a\in A_{i}, d(a,x_{0})\le d(a,x_{i})+d(x_{0},x_{i})\le r_{i}+d_{i}∀a∈Ai​,d(a,x0​)≤d(a,xi​)+d(x0​,xi​)≤ri​+di​.
Hence taking max⁡i{ri+di}\max_{i} \{ r_{i} +d_{i} \}maxi​{ri​+di​} gives the required radius.

Basic Results

  • The limit is unique, just like in R\mathbb{R}R.

Proof: take two limits x,yx,yx,y, and write their distance l=d(x,y)l=d(x,y)l=d(x,y).
Applying the definition with ϵ=l/2\epsilon=l / 2ϵ=l/2 gives a contradiction unless l=0l=0l=0. Then positive-definiteness of the metric gives x=yx=yx=y.

  • All convergent sequences are Cauchy. The converse is not generally true, unlike in R\mathbb{R}R.

Proof: similar to the proof for the uniqueness of the limit. Show that terms are at most ϵ/2\epsilon / 2ϵ/2 around the limit, and use the triangle inequality.

Counterexample to the converse: (1n)⊂(0,1]\left( \frac{1}{n} \right) \subset (0,1](n1​)⊂(0,1] is Cauchy but does not have a limit in the space.

  • As in (R,l2)(\mathbb{R},l_{2})(R,l2​), the sum, modulus, and product of continuous functions are still continuous. And if the denominator is non-zero in the neighborhood, so are the quotients.
  • If f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y is continuous at xxx, and g:Y→Zg:Y\to Zg:Y→Z is continuous at f(x)f(x)f(x), then their composition f∘g:X→Zf \circ g: X \to Zf∘g:X→Z is also continuous at xxx.
  • If f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y is continuous at xxx, and g:U→Vg:U \to Vg:U→V is continuous at uuu, then their “Cartesian product” (f×g):(X×U)→(Y×V)(f \times g):(X \times U)\to(Y \times V)(f×g):(X×U)→(Y×V) is also continuous at (x,u)(x,u)(x,u).

Open/Closedness and Continuity

  • A map f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y is continuous   ⟺  \iff⟺an open subset V⊆YV \subseteq YV⊆Y always has an open preimage f−1(V)⊆Xf^{-1}(V) \subseteq Xf−1(V)⊆X.
    • Continuous functions do not map open sets to open sets in general: take the zero function for example.

Proof:
(⇒\Rightarrow⇒) Assume fff continuous and V⊆YV \subseteq YV⊆Y open. For any point u∈f−1(V)u \in f^{-1}(V)u∈f−1(V), openness of VVV gives ϵ>0:B(f(u),ϵ)⊆V\epsilon>0:B(f(u),\epsilon) \subseteq Vϵ>0:B(f(u),ϵ)⊆V.
Continuity of fff then gives δ>0:f(B(u,δ))⊆B(f(u),ϵ)\delta>0: f(B(u, \delta)) \subseteq B(f(u),\epsilon)δ>0:f(B(u,δ))⊆B(f(u),ϵ). So B(u,δ)B(u, \delta)B(u,δ) is an open ball in the preimage, and hence the preimage is open.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) Any B(f(u),ϵ)B(f(u), \epsilon)B(f(u),ϵ) is open, hence by assumption it has an open preimage. Hence there is a ball B(u,δ)⊆B(u, \delta) \subseteqB(u,δ)⊆ the preimage, satisfying the disk definition of continuity.

  • Similarly, fff continuous   ⟺  \iff⟺ closed subsets have closed preimages.

Proof: apply the previous result on their complements.

Homeomorphisms and Equivalent Metrics

Homeomorphisms

  • A homeomorphism between metric spaces X,YX,YX,Y is a bijection f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y such that both fff and f−1f^{-1}f−1 are continuous.
    • Homeomorphisms are equivalence relations, as compositions of homeomorphisms are also homeomorphisms.
  • R,(a,b),(a,∞),(−∞,a)\mathbb{R},(a,b),(a,\infty),(-\infty,a)R,(a,b),(a,∞),(−∞,a) are all homeomorphic:
    • (−1,1)→R(-1,1) \to \mathbb{R}(−1,1)→R is given by f(x)=x1−∣x∣f(x)=\frac{x}{1-|x|}f(x)=1−∣x∣x​.
    • (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞) is homeomorphic with (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) by the map 1x\frac{1}{x}x1​. Similarly for (−∞,a)(-\infty, a)(−∞,a) via −1x-\frac{1}{x}−x1​.
    • (−1,1)(-1,1)(−1,1) and (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) are homeomorphic with other finite open intervals by shifting and scaling.

Proof (for fff): fff is continuous since the absolute value, quotient, and products are all continuous in the respective intervals. The inverse is continuous since fff continuous and monotone on any interval (continuous inverse function theorem from Prelims Analysis II).

  • Homeomorphisms are open mappings (i.e. they map open sets to open sets)
    • Hence closed sets like [−1,1][-1,1][−1,1] are not homeomorphic to R\mathbb{R}R.

Proof: use the fact that under continuous maps, open sets have open preimages, and apply it to both fff and f−1f^{-1}f−1.

Equivalent Metrics

  • Two metrics d,d~d, \tilde{d}d,d~ on XXX are equivalent if ddd-openness   ⟺  \iff⟺ d~\tilde{d}d~-openness.
    • For example, d1,2,∞d_{1,2,\infty}d1,2,∞​ are all equivalent in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn, but not with the discrete metric.
    • The d1d_{1}d1​ (integral) and d∞d_{\infty}d∞​ (supremum) metrics on C[a,b]C[a,b]C[a,b] are not equivalent: there is no Bd1(0,ϵ)⊆Bd∞(0,1)B^{d_{1}}(0,\epsilon) \subseteq B^{d_{\infty}}(0,1)Bd1​(0,ϵ)⊆Bd∞​(0,1) for any ϵ>0\epsilon >0ϵ>0.
  • Equivalent definition: two metrics are equivalent iff the identity map (X,d)→(X,d~)(X,d) \to (X, \tilde{d})(X,d)→(X,d~) is a homeomorphism.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) bijection is immediate. Then use the fact that “open sets have open preimages” implies continuity for both fff and f−1f^{-1}f−1 , and apply it to the identity map here.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) immediate from the fact that homeomorphisms are open mappings.

  • Continuity is shared in equivalent metrics: if d,d~d, \tilde{d}d,d~ are equivalent in XXX, then for maps X→(Y,dY)X \to (Y, d_{Y})X→(Y,dY​), continuity under (d,dY)(d,d_{Y})(d,dY​)   ⟺  \iff⟺ continuity under (d~,dY)(\tilde{d},d_{Y})(d~,dY​).

Proof: immediate from the equivalence between continuity and “open sets have open pre-images”.

  • Two metrics d1,d2d_{1}, d_{2}d1​,d2​ n XXX are Lipschitz/strongly equivalent: ∃r,R: ∀x,y∈X, rd2(x,y)≤d1(x,y)≤Rd2(x,y)\exists r,R:\, \forall x,y \in X,\,rd_{2}(x,y) \le d_{1}(x,y) \le Rd_{2}(x,y)∃r,R:∀x,y∈X,rd2​(x,y)≤d1​(x,y)≤Rd2​(x,y)

    • Note that d1,d2,d∞d_{1},d_{2},d_\inftyd1​,d2​,d∞​ in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn are Libschitz equivalent.

  • Lipschitz equivalence implies equivalence.

Proof: we show that d1d_{1}d1​-openness implies d2d_{2}d2​ openness. The other way around is symmetric.

Lipschitz equivalence guarantees that any d1d_{1}d1​-open ball Bd1(x,δ)B^{d_{1}}(x,\delta)Bd1​(x,δ) contains a d2d_{2}d2​-open ball Bd2(x,δ/r)B^{d_{2}}(x,\delta / r)Bd2​(x,δ/r). So if XXX is d1d_{1}d1​-open, any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X has a d2d_{2}d2​-open ball around it, hence XXX is also d2d_{2}d2​-open.

Completeness

  • A metric space XXX is complete if all Cauchy sequences in the space converges.
    • For example, R\mathbb{R}R is complete, but Q\mathbb{Q}Q and (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) are not. Hence completeness is not preserved under homeomorphisms, as R\mathbb{R}R is homeomorphic to (0,1)(0,1)(0,1).

Criteria for Completeness

  • Closedness equals completeness: if Y⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X, XXX complete, then YYY complete   ⟺  \iff⟺ YYY is closed in XXX.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) all y∈L(Y)y \in L(Y)y∈L(Y) have a sequence (yn)⊆Y:(yn)→y(y_{n})\subseteq Y:(y_{n})\to y(yn​)⊆Y:(yn​)→y. (yn)(y_{n})(yn​) must be Cauchy since it converges, and so YYY complete means y∈Yy\in Yy∈Y. So L(Y)⊆YL(Y)\subseteq YL(Y)⊆Y, YYY closed.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) take Cauchy sequence (yn)⊆Y⊆X(y_{n})\subseteq Y\subseteq X(yn​)⊆Y⊆X, and since XXX complete, ∃y:(yn)→y\exists y:(y_{n})\to y∃y:(yn​)→y, and yyy must be a limit point of YYY. Since YYY closed, y∈Yy\in Yy∈Y, and hence YYY complete.

  • A product space is complete   ⟺  \iff⟺ all its components are complete.
    • As a corollary, Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is complete since R\mathbb{R}R is complete.

Hint: although the usual product space is defined with the “d2d_{2}d2​” distance, that is dprod=dX2+dY2d_{\text{prod}}=\sqrt{d_{X}^2+d_{Y}^2}dprod​=dX2​+dY2​​, by Lipschitz equivalence of d1,d2,d∞d_{1},d_{2},d_{\infty}d1​,d2​,d∞​, we can prove the result for dprod=max⁡(dX,dY)d_{\text{prod}}=\max(d_{X},d_{Y})dprod​=max(dX​,dY​) instead.
Then just work out the details for Cauchy-ness and convergence.

  • Completeness is perserved by a “uniform homeomorphism”, a bijection f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y where f,f−1f, f^{-1}f,f−1 are both uniformly continuous.
    • As a result, completeness is preserved in switching between Lipschitz/strongly equivalent metrics (consider the switch as the identity map (X,d)→(X,d~)(X,d) \to (X,\tilde{d})(X,d)→(X,d~))

Proof: say fff is a uniform homeomorphism, with d(x1,x2)<δ⇒d(f(x1),f(x2))<ϵd(x_{1},x_{2})<\delta \Rightarrow d(f(x_{1}),f(x_{2}))<\epsilond(x1​,x2​)<δ⇒d(f(x1​),f(x2​))<ϵ, the same δ\deltaδ valid for all x1,x2x_{1},x_{2}x1​,x2​. We shall show that (1) fff maps Cauchy sequences to Cauchy sequences, and (2) preserves its convergence.

Cauchy-to-Cauchy: given Cauchy sequence (xn)(x_{n})(xn​), taking m,nm,nm,n large such that d(xm,xn)<δd(x_{m},x_{n})<\deltad(xm​,xn​)<δ means that the image-sequence d(f(xm),f(xn))<ϵd(f(x_{m}),f(x_{n}))< \epsilond(f(xm​),f(xn​))<ϵ, giving Cauchiness.

Convergence: Given ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0, uniform continuity gives δ\deltaδ. Since XXX is complete, the Cauchy sequence (xn)→x∈X(x_{n}) \to x \in X(xn​)→x∈X. Take kkk large so that d(xk,x)<δd(x_{k}, x)<\deltad(xk​,x)<δ, so d(f(xk),f(x))<ϵd(f(x_{k}),f(x))<\epsilond(f(xk​),f(x))<ϵ. So the Cauchy sequence (f(xn))(f(x_{n}))(f(xn​)) converges to f(x)∈Yf(x)\in Yf(x)∈Y (note that fff being bijection guarantees inclusion).

  • Cantor’s intersection theorem: in a complete metric space XXX, S1⊇S2⊇S3…, diam(Sn)→0S_{1} \supseteq S_{2} \supseteq S_{3} \dots,\,\mathrm{diam}(S_{n}) \to 0S1​⊇S2​⊇S3​…,diam(Sn​)→0, SiS_{i}Si​ are all closed and non-empty, then ∩iSi={a}\cap_{i}S_{i}=\{ a \}∩i​Si​={a} for some a∈Xa \in Xa∈X.

Proof:
Finding the point: take xn∈Snx_{n} \in S_{n}xn​∈Sn​, then the sequence (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) is Cauchy. For any ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0, find k:diam(Sk)<ϵk:\mathrm{diam(S_{k})}<\epsilonk:diam(Sk​)<ϵ. Completeness of XXX guarantees convergence (xn)→a(x_{n}) \to a(xn​)→a.

Non-emptiness: since the tail (an≥k)⊆Sk(a_{n \ge k}) \subseteq S_{k}(an≥k​)⊆Sk​, aaa is a limit point of SkS_{k}Sk​, so SkS_{k}Sk​ closed implies a∈Ska \in S_{k}a∈Sk​. Since this is true for all kkk, a∈∩iSia \in \cap_{i} S_{i}a∈∩i​Si​.

Completeness of Function Spaces

  • (B(X),d∞)\big(B(X),d_{\infty}\big)(B(X),d∞​) is complete, where B(X)B(X)B(X) is the set of bounded functions X→RX\to \mathbb{R}X→R.

Proof: take a Cauchy sequence (fn)⊆B(X)(f_{n})\subseteq B(X)(fn​)⊆B(X).
The limit: (fn)(f_{n})(fn​) Cauchy means that at each point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, (fn(x))⊆R(f_{n}(x))\subseteq \mathbb{R}(fn​(x))⊆R is a Cauchy sequence. So by completeness of R\mathbb{R}R, the sequence converges pointwise to f(x)≡lim⁡n→∞fn(x)f(x)\equiv \lim_{ n \to \infty }f_{n}(x)f(x)≡limn→∞​fn​(x).

Boundedness, so that f∈B(X)f \in B(X)f∈B(X):

Then at any x0∈Xx_{0}\in Xx0​∈X, ∣fN(x0)−fn(x0)∣<1|f_{N}(x_{0})-f_{n}(x_{0})|<1∣fN​(x0​)−fn​(x0​)∣<1.
So AOL gives ∣fN(x0)−f(x0)∣≤1|f_{N}(x_{0})-f(x_{0})|\le 1∣fN​(x0​)−f(x0​)∣≤1, so f(x0)≤fN(x0)+1f(x_{0}) \le f_{N}(x_{0})+1f(x0​)≤fN​(x0​)+1. Since fNf_{N}fN​ is bounded, so is fff.

Convergence in d∞d_{\infty}d∞​: Cauchy-ness gives N:∀m,n≥N, ∣fm(x)−fn(x)∣<ϵN:\forall m,n\ge N,\, |f_{m}(x)-f_{n}(x)|<\epsilonN:∀m,n≥N,∣fm​(x)−fn​(x)∣<ϵ, the same NNN applicable at ∀x∈X\forall x \in X∀x∈X.
so letting m→∞m \to \inftym→∞ gives N:∀n≥N,x∈X, ∣f(x)−fn(x)∣≤ϵN:\forall n\ge N,x \in X,\, |f(x)-f_{n}(x)|\le\epsilonN:∀n≥N,x∈X,∣f(x)−fn​(x)∣≤ϵ, which is by definition (fn)undefinedd∞f(f_{n}) \xrightarrow{d_{\infty}} f(fn​)d∞​​f.

  • The metric space of continuous functions over a metric space (X,d)→R(X,d) \to \mathbb{R}(X,d)→R, (C(X),d∞)(C(X),d_{\infty})(C(X),d∞​) is complete.

Proof: take a Cauchy sequence (fn)⊆C(X)(f_{n}) \subseteq C(X)(fn​)⊆C(X). Since B(X)B(X)B(X) is complete, it has a limit (fn)→f∈B(X)(f_{n}) \to f \in B(X)(fn​)→f∈B(X). We shall show that fff is continuous, so f∈C(X)f \in C(X)f∈C(X). However, convergence under the d∞d_{\infty}d∞​ metric is in fact uniform convergence, hence continuity of fnf_{n}fn​ implies continuity of fff.

Connectedness and Path Connectedness

  • A metric space XXX is disconnected if it can be partitioned by two open, non-empty subsets of it, that is: ∃A,B open⊊X: A∩B=∅, A∪B=X, \exists A,B\text{ open} \subsetneq X:\, A \cap B= \emptyset,\, A \cup B = X,\,∃A,B open⊊X:A∩B=∅,A∪B=X,and otherwise it is connected.
  • Equivalent definition: XXX is connected iff any continuous map f:X→({0,1},ddiscrete)f: X \to (\{ 0,1 \}, d_\text{discrete})f:X→({0,1},ddiscrete​) must be constant.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) {0}\{ 0 \}{0}, being open under the discrete metric, has an open pre-image under fff. So does {1}\{ 1 \}{1}. But then their pre-image would form a partition of XXX by open sets, a contradiction unless one of the pre-images is empty. Hence fff constant.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) If for contradiction XXX is disconnected by A,BA,BA,B, then the map f=1x∈Af=\mathbb{1}_{x \in A}f=1x∈A​ is continuous but not constant, a contradiction.

  • Another equivalent definition: XXX is connected iff the only subsets of XXX that are both open and closed are XXX and ∅\emptyset∅.

Criteria for Connectedness

  • Connectness is preserved by continuous maps: under a continuous map, the image of a connected space is also connected.
    • Hence in particular, connectedness is shared by homeomorphic spaces.

Proof: suppose that f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y, XXX connected, and for contradiction f(X)f(X)f(X) is disconnected by A,B⊂f(X)A, B \subset f(X)A,B⊂f(X), A,BA,BA,B both open and non-empty.
Then f−1(A)f^{-1}(A)f−1(A) and f−1(B)f^{-1}(B)f−1(B) are non-empty, open (being preimages of open sets), and disconnect XXX, a contradiction.

  • If AAA is connected, so is any B:A⊆B⊆AˉB:A \subseteq B \subseteq \bar{A}B:A⊆B⊆Aˉ.
    • In particular, if a set is connected, so is its closure.

Proof: we show that any continuous function f:B→{0,1}f:B \to \{ 0,1 \}f:B→{0,1} must be constant. Note that f∣Af|_{A}f∣A​ is still continuous, so connectedness of AAA requires f∣Af|_{A}f∣A​ constant.
Then for any b∈Bb \in Bb∈B, either b∈Ab \in Ab∈A and the result is immediate, or b∈L(A)∖Ab \in L(A)\setminus Ab∈L(A)∖A. So there is (an)⊆A:(an)→b(a_{n}) \subseteq A: (a_{n}) \to b(an​)⊆A:(an​)→b. Continuity of fff requires (f(an))→f(b)(f(a_{n})) \to f(b)(f(an​))→f(b), so f(b)=f(A)f(b)=f(A)f(b)=f(A). Hence f(B)=f(A)f(B)=f(A)f(B)=f(A) constant.

  • The sunflower lemma: in a metric space XXX, given a collection of connected subsets {Ai}⊆P(X)\{ A_{i} \} \subseteq \mathcal{P}(X){Ai​}⊆P(X) satisfying Ai∩Aj≠∅A_{i}\cap A_{j}\ne \emptysetAi​∩Aj​=∅, their union ∪iAi\cup_{i} A_{i}∪i​Ai​ is also connected.
    • This version is stronger than the lemma in the notes, but is easier(?) to prove. It doesn’t look like a sunflower, though.
    • This name “sunflower lemma” is not used anywhere other than in the lecture notes, so I’m not sure if it’s safe to quote by name only.

Proof: we will show that any continuous function f:∪iAi→{0,1}f: \cup_{i}A_{i} \to \{ 0,1 \}f:∪i​Ai​→{0,1} must be constant. Define bi=f(xi)b_{i}=f(x_{i})bi​=f(xi​) for some xi∈Aix_{i} \in A_{i}xi​∈Ai​, well-defined since f∣Aif|_{A_{i}}f∣Ai​​ is constant due to continuity and connectness.

Then for any i,ji,ji,j, there is xij∈Ai∩Aj≠∅x_{ij}\in A_{i} \cap A_{j} \ne \emptysetxij​∈Ai​∩Aj​=∅, so bi=f(xij)=bjb_{i}=f(x_{ij})=b_{j}bi​=f(xij​)=bj​. So fff must be constant.

Connectedness in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn

Big idea: interval equals connectedness.

  • A set S⊆RS \subseteq \mathbb{R}S⊆R has the interval property if x,y∈Sx,y \in Sx,y∈S, then [x,y]⊆S[x,y] \subseteq S[x,y]⊆S.
    • That is, if two points are in the set, so are anything between them.
  • In R\mathbb{R}R, a set is an interval   ⟺  \iff⟺ it has the interval property.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) immediate.
(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) Work with a=inf⁡S,b=sup⁡Sa=\inf S,b=\sup Sa=infS,b=supS, replacing them with ±∞\pm \infty±∞ if necessary, and show that (a,b)⊆S⊆[a,b](a,b) \subseteq S \subseteq [a,b](a,b)⊆S⊆[a,b].

  • S⊆RS \subseteq \mathbb{R}S⊆R is connected   ⟺  \iff⟺ SSS is an interval.
    • Hence Q\mathbb{Q}Q is not connected.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒) if for contradiction the connected set SSS fails the interval property, there is x,y∈S,z∈(x,y):z∉Sx,y \in S, z\in (x,y): z\not \in Sx,y∈S,z∈(x,y):z∈S. Then verify that S−={s∈S:s<z}S_{-}=\{ s\in S: s<z \}S−​={s∈S:s<z} and S+={s∈S:s>z}S_{+}= \{ s \in S: s>z \}S+​={s∈S:s>z} disconnect SSS.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) Note that if (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) is connected, so is [a,b]=Closure((a,b))[a,b]=\text{Closure}((a,b))[a,b]=Closure((a,b)) (a,ba,ba,b can be ±∞\pm \infty±∞ in this case). But (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) is homeomorphic to R\mathbb{R}R, which is connected. Since homeomorphisms preserve connectedness, all intervals are connected.

  • Continuous maps f:X→Rf: X \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R map connected spaces to intervals; in particular, the intermediate value theorem holds.

Proof: fff continuous must map connected spaces XXX to connected subspaces in R\mathbb{R}R, which must be an interval. Any intermediate value would have a non-empty preimage, then.

Path-Connectedness

  • A path in a metric space XXX is a continuous map p:[0,1]→Xp: [0,1] \to Xp:[0,1]→X

    • If we write x=p(0)x=p(0)x=p(0) and y=p(1)y=p(1)y=p(1), then the path fff “joins” xxx and yyy.

  • A metric space XXX is path-connected if any two points in XXX can be joined by a path in XXX.

    • For example, the unit circle in (R2,d2)(\mathbb{R}^{2},d_{2})(R2,d2​) is connected; R∖{0}\mathbb{R}\setminus \{ 0 \}R∖{0} is not connected, but R2∖{0}\mathbb{R}^{2}\setminus \{ 0 \}R2∖{0} is.

  • Being connected by a path is an equivalent relation; the partition of the space into path-connected subsets is called path-components.

  • Path-connectedness implies connectedness. The converse is not necessarily true.

Proof: if for contradiction XXX is path-connected but not connected, then there is continuous function f:X→{0,1}f: X \to \{ 0,1 \}f:X→{0,1} not constant, say ∃x,y∈X:f(x)≠f(y)\exists x,y \in X:f(x)\ne f(y)∃x,y∈X:f(x)=f(y).
But path-connectedness gives a path ρ\rhoρ joining x,yx,yx,y, so f∘ρf \circ \rhof∘ρ gives a continuous, non-constant map [0,1]→{0,1}[0,1] \to \{ 0,1 \}[0,1]→{0,1}, a contradiction to [0,1][0,1][0,1] being connected.

Counterexample to the converse: google “Topologist’s sine curve”.

  • Nevertheless, connected normed vector spaces are path-connected.

Proof: assume for contradiction the normed vector space VVV is connected but not path-connected. Then there are multiple path-components, and we shall show that they disconnect XXX. Since partition is immediate, it remains to show that these components are open.

Take any v∈Vv \in Vv∈V and its path-component CvC_{v}Cv​. Since VVV itself is open, there is ϵ:B(v,ϵ)⊆V\epsilon: B(v,\epsilon) \subseteq Vϵ:B(v,ϵ)⊆V. To see that B(v,ϵ)⊆CvB(v, \epsilon) \subseteq C_{v}B(v,ϵ)⊆Cv​, fix any u∈B(v,ϵ)u \in B(v,\epsilon)u∈B(v,ϵ) and u,vu,vu,v can be joined with the path p(λ)=λu+(1−λ)vp(\lambda)=\lambda u+(1-\lambda)vp(λ)=λu+(1−λ)v. Hence the ball B(a,ϵ)⊆CaB(a, \epsilon) \subseteq C_{a}B(a,ϵ)⊆Ca​, the path-component is open.

Sequential Compactness

Big idea: sequential compactness is the generalization of Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem from the real numbers.

  • A metric space XXX is sequentially compact if any sequence (xn)⊆X(x_{n}) \subseteq X(xn​)⊆X has a convergent subsequence.
    • For example, by Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem in the reals, any closed, bounded subset of R\mathbb{R}R is sequentially compact.

Criteria for Sequential Compactness

  • A sequentially compact subspace A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X must be bounded and closed; the converse is not true in general.

Proof: suppose AAA is sequentially compact.
Closedness: if for contradiction AAA is not closed, there is a limit point a∉Aa \not\in Aa∈A, and being a limit point, it has a sequence A⊇(an)→aA \supseteq (a_{n}) \to aA⊇(an​)→a in XXX. Then any subsequence (ank)→a∉A(a_{n_{k}}) \to a \not \in A(ank​​)→a∈A, a contradiction.

Boundedness: If for contradiction AAA is unbounded, then from an arbitrary point p∈Ap \in Ap∈A, for any distance n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N, there is a point further away: ∃an∈A:d(p,an)>n\exists a_{n} \in A: d(p,a_{n})>n∃an​∈A:d(p,an​)>n. Then the sequence (an)(a_{n})(an​) has no convergent subsequence (any “limit” aaa would have d(a,an)>d(an,p)−d(p,a)→∞d(a,a_{n})>d(a_{n},p) - d(p,a) \to \inftyd(a,an​)>d(an​,p)−d(p,a)→∞).

Counterexample to the converse: (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) is closed and bounded in itself, but is not sequentially compact.

  • Sequential compactness is preserved by continuous maps.
    • In particular, sequential compactness is shared by homeomorphic spaces.

Proof: say f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y continuous, and XXX is sequentially compact. Take any (yn)⊆Y(y_{n}) \subseteq Y(yn​)⊆Y, with preimage (xn)≡(f−1(yn))(x_{n})\equiv(f^{-1}(y_{n}))(xn​)≡(f−1(yn​)). Sequential compactness of XXX gives subsequence (xnk)→x∈X(x_{n_{k}}) \to x \in X(xnk​​)→x∈X.
Continuity of fff then guarantees ynk=f(xnk)→f(x)∈Yy_{n_{k}}=f(x_{n_{k}}) \to f(x) \in Yynk​​=f(xnk​​)→f(x)∈Y. Hence (yn)⊆Y(y_{n}) \subseteq Y(yn​)⊆Y has a convergent subsequence.

  • Products of sequentially compact spaces are also sequentially compact.

Proof: Take X,YX, YX,Y sequentially compact and sequences (xn)⊆X,(yn)⊆Y(x_{n})\subseteq X,(y_{n}) \subseteq Y(xn​)⊆X,(yn​)⊆Y.
Then XXX sequentially compact gives a convergent subsequence (xnk)→x(x_{n_{k}}) \to x(xnk​​)→x. Take (γk)=(ynk)⊆Y(\gamma_{k})=(y_{n_{k}}) \subseteq Y(γk​)=(ynk​​)⊆Y, then sequential compactness of YYY gives (γkr)→y(\gamma_{k_{r}}) \to y(γkr​​)→y convergent.
So (xnkr,ynkr)→(x,y)(x_{n_{k_{r}}},y_{n_{k_{r}}}) \to (x,y)(xnkr​​​,ynkr​​​)→(x,y) is a convergent subsequence of ((xn,yn))((x_{n}, y_{n}))((xn​,yn​)), so X×YX \times YX×Y is sequentially compact.

  • Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem on Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn: any closed, bounded subset of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is sequentially compact.

Proof: say X⊆RnX \subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn closed and bounded in [−M,M]n[-M,M]^n[−M,M]n. Then by the previous result, [−M,M]n[-M,M]^n[−M,M]n is sequentially compact. Since XXX is a closed subset of it, XXX is also sequentially compact.

  • Heine-Cantor Theorem: any continuous map from a sequentially compact space must be uniformly continuous.
    • in particular, any continuous map f:X→Rf: X \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R, XXX sequentially compact, must be uniformly continuous.

Proof: say there is a continuous map f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y, XXX is sequentially compact. Suppose for contradiction fff is not uniformly continuous.
So there ∃ϵ>0\exists\epsilon>0∃ϵ>0, for which any δ=1/n,n∈N\delta=1 / n, n \in \mathbb{N}δ=1/n,n∈N, there is exception (an,bn):dX(an,bn)<δ(a_{n},b_{n}):d_{X}(a_{n},b_{n})<\delta(an​,bn​):dX​(an​,bn​)<δ, but dY(f(an),f(bn))≥ϵd_{Y}(f(a_{n}),f(b_{n})) \ge \epsilondY​(f(an​),f(bn​))≥ϵ.

By sequential compactness, there is a subsequence (ank,bnk)→(l,l)(a_{n_{k}},b_{n_{k}}) \to (l,l)(ank​​,bnk​​)→(l,l), where the limits are both lll since dX(an,bn)→0d_{X}(a_{n},b_{n}) \to 0dX​(an​,bn​)→0. But then continuity of fff requires (f(ank),f(bnk))→(f(l),f(l))(f(a_{n_{k}}),f(b_{n_{k}})) \to (f(l),f(l))(f(ank​​),f(bnk​​))→(f(l),f(l)), contradictory to dY(f(an),f(bn))≥ϵd_{Y}(f(a_{n}),f(b_{n})) \ge \epsilondY​(f(an​),f(bn​))≥ϵ.

Sequential Compactness and Completeness

  • Sequential compactness implies completeness and boundedness.

Proof: take XXX sequentially compact and Cauchy sequence (xk)⊆X(x_{k}) \subseteq X(xk​)⊆X with convergent subsequence (xkr)→x(x_{k_{r}}) \to x(xkr​​)→x. Boundedness is already shown in the previous section.

For completeness, we shall show that (xn)→x(x_{n}) \to x(xn​)→x, the big idea being that since the sequence is Cauchy, the convergent subsequence wil “drag” the entire sequence with it towards the limit.

Given ϵ>0\epsilon >0ϵ>0, take the indices where the subsequence grows close enough to the limit: K={kr:d(xkr,x)<ϵ}K=\{ k_{r}: d(x_{k_{r}},x) < \epsilon \}K={kr​:d(xkr​​,x)<ϵ}. Cauchy-ness gives l:∀m,n≥l,d(xm,xn)<ϵl: \forall m,n \ge l, d(x_{m}, x_{n})< \epsilonl:∀m,n≥l,d(xm​,xn​)<ϵ. In particular, take m∈Km \in Km∈K, so that xmx_{m}xm​ can “drag” xnx_{n}xn​ to the limit:d(x,xn)<d(x,xm)+d(xn,xm)<2ϵd(x,x_{n})<d(x,x_{m})+d(x_{n},x_{m}) < 2\epsilond(x,xn​)<d(x,xm​)+d(xn​,xm​)<2ϵSo (xn)→x(x_{n}) \to x(xn​)→x, and the space is complete.

  • The converse is not true in general: in Bˉ(0,1)⊆(B(R),d∞)\bar{B}(0,1) \subseteq (B(\mathbb{R}),d_{\infty})Bˉ(0,1)⊆(B(R),d∞​) is bounded and complete, but not sequentially compact.

Proof:
Boundedness is immediate.

It is complete is because of Bˉ(0,1)\bar{B}(0,1)Bˉ(0,1) being a closed subset of B(R)B(\mathbb{R})B(R), a complete metric space.

It is not sequentially compact because the sequence indicator functions fn=χ[n,n+1]f_{n}=\chi_{[n,n+1]}fn​=χ[n,n+1]​ always has d∞(fn,fm)=δmnd_{\infty}(f_{n},f_{m})=\delta_{mn}d∞​(fn​,fm​)=δmn​, so there is no Cauchy (hence convergent) subsequence.

  • A space is totally bounded if for any radius r>0r>0r>0, the space can be covered by finitely many open balls of radius rrr: ∃ finite {xi}⊆X:X⊆⋃iB(xi,r)\exists \text{ finite } \{ x_{i} \} \subseteq X:X \subseteq\bigcup_{i} B(x_{i}, r)∃ finite {xi​}⊆X:X⊆i⋃​B(xi​,r)
  • A space is sequentially compact   ⟺  \iff⟺ it is complete and totally bounded.

Proof: (⇒\Rightarrow⇒ totally bounded) suppose for contradiction there is a radius ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0 such that the space cannot be covered by finitely many balls of radius ϵ\epsilonϵ.
Then inductively taking an element xnx_{n}xn​ from each ball gives a sequence (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) with no Cauchy subsequences (each element is at least ϵ\epsilonϵ from each other), hence no convergent subsequences, a contradiction.

(⇐\Leftarrow⇐) Given a sequence σ=(xn)⊆X\sigma=(x_{n}) \subseteq Xσ=(xn​)⊆X, we construct a Cauchy subsequence explicitly, then completeness will guarantee its convergence.
For n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N, let Bn\mathcal{B}_{n}Bn​ be the finite family of balls of radius 2−n2^{-n}2−n that covers the space.
Start with n=0n=0n=0, and at least one of the balls B0∈B0B_{0} \in \mathcal{B}_{0}B0​∈B0​ contains an infinite number of terms of σ\sigmaσ, so take the subsequence σ0=σ∩B0\sigma_{0}=\sigma \cap B_{0}σ0​=σ∩B0​.
Now increment to n=1n=1n=1, and one of the balls B1∈B1B_{1} \in \mathcal{B}_{1}B1​∈B1​ contains infinitely many terms of σ0\sigma_{0}σ0​, giving a new subsequence σ1=σ0∩B1\sigma_{1} =\sigma_{0} \cap B_{1}σ1​=σ0​∩B1​.
Repeat for each n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N, and we get subsequences (σn)(\sigma_{n})(σn​) where σi+1⊆σi∩Bi+1\sigma_{i+1} \subseteq \sigma_{i} \cap B_{i+1}σi+1​⊆σi​∩Bi+1​, and radius (Bi)=2−i\text{radius }(B_{i})=2^{-i}radius (Bi​)=2−i.
Then we can construct a new subsequence (χn)⊆(xn)(\chi_{n}) \subseteq (x_{n})(χn​)⊆(xn​) by taking the nnnth term of σn\sigma_{n}σn​. Since (χn≥k)⊆Bk(\chi_{n \ge k}) \subseteq B_{k}(χn≥k​)⊆Bk​, they can only be at most 2k−12^{k-1}2k−1 apart, so this subsequence is Cauchy. Then completeness gives (χn)→χ(\chi_{n}) \to \chi(χn​)→χ, a convergent subsequence of (xn)(x_{n})(xn​).

Arzelà-Ascoli Theorem: Sequential Compactness in Function Spaces

Big idea: (C(X),d∞)(C(X),d_{\infty})(C(X),d∞​) is not sequentially compact, but some extra restrictions could make it so.

  • The space of continuous functions over a sequentially compact spase XXX, C(X)C(X)C(X) is not sequentially compact: in C(R)C(\mathbb{R})C(R),
    • The supremum of the functions can tend to infinity: (fn)=(n)(f_{n})=(n)(fn​)=(n) has no convergent subsequence.
    • The functions can be increasingly steep, so they are all distant from each other under d∞d_{\infty}d∞​: consider the piecewise linear functions (fn):fn={0if x≤1n+1n(n+1)(x−1n+1)if 1n+1<x≤1n1if x>1n(f_{n}): f_{n}=\begin{cases}0 & \text{if }x \le \frac{1}{n+1} \\ n(n+1)(x-\frac{1}{n+1}) &\text{if } \frac{1}{n+1}<x \le \frac{1}{n}\\ 1 &\text{if }x> \frac{1}{n} \end{cases}(fn​):fn​=⎩⎨⎧​0n(n+1)(x−n+11​)1​if x≤n+11​if n+11​<x≤n1​if x>n1​​where d∞(fm,fn)=1d_{\infty}(f_{m},f_{n})=1d∞​(fm​,fn​)=1 when m≠nm \ne nm=n.
  • However, Arzelà-Ascoli states that as long as these two types of exceptions are removed, the space is sequentially compact.
  • A family of functions {fn}\{ f_{n} \}{fn​} is uniformly bounded if they share the same bound: ∃M:∀n, sup⁡∣fn∣≤M\exists M: \forall n,\, \sup|f_{n}| \le M∃M:∀n,sup∣fn​∣≤M. This rules out the tending-to-infinity type of exceptions.
  • A family of continuous functions {fn}\{ f_{n} \}{fn​} is equicontinuous if given ϵ>0\epsilon >0ϵ>0, the same δ\deltaδ suffices for the ϵ−δ\epsilon-\deltaϵ−δ definition of continuity for all fnf_{n}fn​: ∀ϵ>0, ∃δ>0:∀n, (d(x,y)<δ)⇒∣fn(x)−fn(y)∣<ϵ\forall \epsilon>0,\, \exists \delta>0:\forall n,\, (d(x,y)<\delta) \Rightarrow |f_{n}(x)-f_{n}(y)| < \epsilon∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0:∀n,(d(x,y)<δ)⇒∣fn​(x)−fn​(y)∣<ϵThis rules out the increasingly-steep type of exceptions.
  • Arzelà-Ascoli: over a sequentially compact space XXX, F⊆C(X)F \subseteq C(X)F⊆C(X) is uniformly bounded and equicontinuous, then any sequence in FFF has a subsequence convergent in C(X)C(X)C(X). Hence if FFF is closed, it is also sequentially compact.

Proof is not examinable.

Compactness

  • In a metric space XXX, a cover of A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X is a family of subsets {Ui⊆X}\{ U_{i} \subseteq X \}{Ui​⊆X} where A⊆⋃iUiA \subseteq \bigcup_{i}U_{i}A⊆⋃i​Ui​.

    • For example, {B(k,2):k∈Z}\{ B(k,2): k \in \mathbb{Z} \}{B(k,2):k∈Z} is a cover of R\mathbb{R}R.

  • The set {Uik}⊆{Ui}\{ U_{i_{k}} \} \subseteq \{ U_{i} \}{Uik​​}⊆{Ui​} is a subcover if it is still a cover of AAA; if it has finitely many members, it is a finite subcover.

    • For example, {B(2k,2)}\{ B(2k,2) \}{B(2k,2)} is a subcover of the previous example.
    • Note that finiteness referrs to the number of “patches”, not the size: {(−∞,∞)}\{ (-\infty, \infty) \}{(−∞,∞)} is a finite cover of R\mathbb{R}R.

  • A cover is an open cover if all its family members UiU_{i}Ui​ are open in XXX.

    • The previous examples are open covers since B(k,2)B(k,2)B(k,2) is open in R\mathbb{R}R.

  • A subset AAA is compact if every open cover has a finite subcover.

    • For example, (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) is not compact in R\mathbb{R}R, since the open cover {(1n,1):n∈Z+}\left\{ \left( \frac{1}{n}, 1 \right) : n \in \mathbb{Z}^+\right\}{(n1​,1):n∈Z+} has no finite subcover.

  • Compact subsets are bounded.

    • Hence for example R\mathbb{R}R is not compact.

Proof: take A⊆XA \subseteq XA⊆X, AAA compact, but for contradiction assume that around ppp, any radius n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N has an∈A:d(p,an)>na_{n} \in A: d(p,a_{n}) >nan​∈A:d(p,an​)>n.
Then the set {B(p,n):n∈N}\{ B(p,n): n \in \mathbb{N} \}{B(p,n):n∈N} is an open cover of AAA that has no finite subcover, a contradiction.

Compactness and Sequential Compactness

Big idea: they are the same (in metric spaces).

  • Compactness implies sequential compactness in metric spaces.

This a proof from Sutherland (2009). Take (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) from a compact space XXX. We will show that it has a convergent subsequence.

Lemma: given sequence (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) with x:∀ϵ>0, B(x,ϵ)x:\forall \epsilon>0,\, B(x,\epsilon)x:∀ϵ>0,B(x,ϵ) contains infinitely many terms of (xn)(x_{n})(xn​), then there is a subsequence (xnk)→x(x_{n_{k}}) \to x(xnk​​)→x.

Proof:
We construct the subsequence inductively; start with xn1∈B(x,1)x_{n_{1}}\in B(x,1)xn1​​∈B(x,1), which exists by assumption.
Then we construct xnk+1x_{n_{k+1}}xnk+1​​ given xnkx_{n_{k}}xnk​​: since (xn≥nk)(x_{n \ge n_{k}})(xn≥nk​​) has infinitely many terms within B(x,1k+1)B\left( x, \frac{1}{k+1} \right)B(x,k+11​), we can take a xnk+1x_{n_{k+1}}xnk+1​​ from that.
So (xnk)→x(x_{n_{k}}) \to x(xnk​​)→x, and it is a subsequence of (xn)(x_{n})(xn​).

We will use its contrapositive: that if there are no convergent subsequences in (xn)(x_{n})(xn​), then ∀x, ∃ϵ>0:B(x,ϵ)\forall x,\,\exists \epsilon>0: B(x,\epsilon)∀x,∃ϵ>0:B(x,ϵ) contains only finitely many of (xn)(x_{n})(xn​).

Proof: assume for contradiction (xn)(x_{n})(xn​) has no convergent subsequence. Then by the lemma, all xxx has ϵ:Bx=B(x,ϵ)\epsilon: B_{x}=B(x,\epsilon)ϵ:Bx​=B(x,ϵ) contains finitely many terms of (xn)(x_{n})(xn​).
The open cover {Bx:x∈X}\{ B_{x}: x \in X \}{Bx​:x∈X} has no finite subcover, since any finite subset contains only finitely many terms of (xn)(x_{n})(xn​), hence not covering it, a contradiction.

  • Sequential compactness implies compactness.

Proof is not examinable.

Heine-Borel Theorem: Compactness in the Reals

  • Heine Borel: any closed, bounded interval [a,b]⊂R[a,b] \subset \mathbb{R}[a,b]⊂R is compact.

Obviously [a,b][a,b][a,b] is totally bounded and complete, hence sequentially compact, hence compact. Instead of this, Oxford wants the direct proof below. FML.

Proof: given an open cover U={Ui}\mathcal{U}=\{ U_{i} \}U={Ui​}, define the set S={c∈[a,b]:[a,c] has a finite subcover}S= \big\{ c \in [a,b]: [a,c] \text{ has a finite subcover} \big\}S={c∈[a,b]:[a,c] has a finite subcover} and s=sup⁡Ss=\sup Ss=supS. We will show that s=bs=bs=b.
Denote U(x)∈UU^{(x)} \in \mathcal{U}U(x)∈U as some patch in the cover containing xxx.
Obviously s>as> as>a, since ∃ϵ>0:B(a,ϵ)⊆U(a)\exists \epsilon>0: B(a,\epsilon) \subseteq U^{(a)}∃ϵ>0:B(a,ϵ)⊆U(a), so a+ϵ2∈Sa+\frac{\epsilon}{2} \in Sa+2ϵ​∈S.
Assume for contradiction that s≠bs \ne bs=b. Then since U(s)U^{(s)}U(s) open, so it contains B(s,η)B(s, \eta)B(s,η) for some ∣b−s∣>η>0|b-s|>\eta >0∣b−s∣>η>0. But then s+η2∈Ss+ \frac{\eta}{2} \in Ss+2η​∈S, contradictory to the definition of s=sup⁡Ss=\sup Ss=supS. Hence b=sup⁡Sb = \sup Sb=supS.
There is r:B(b,r)⊆U(b)r:B(b,r) \subseteq U^{(b)}r:B(b,r)⊆U(b). Since bbb is sup⁡S\sup SsupS, the approximation theorem gives c∈S:∣b−c∣<rc \in S: |b-c|< rc∈S:∣b−c∣<r.
Then [a,c][a,c][a,c] has a finite subcover U[a,c]⊆U\mathcal{U}_{[a,c]} \subseteq \mathcal{U}U[a,c]​⊆U. So the union U[a,c]∪{U(b)}\mathcal{U}_{[a,c]} \cup \{ U^{(b)}\}U[a,c]​∪{U(b)} is a finite subcover of U\mathcal{U}U.
